objects.title: Wedding Dress of Margaret A. Heminway

properties.value: Wedding Dress of Margaret A. Heminway

Dress of cream silk taffeta; lining made of off-white polished cotton; crinoline silhouette; boned bodice, barrel-chested, princess seams in back, three waist darts in front; high neckline, finished with fine piping of about 1/6"; cap sleeves with two ruffles; boning at center back and through the front; brass hooks and eyes at center back; piped waistline; very full skirt, required hoop skirt; floor length; at the waistline cartridge pleats in back and knife pleats at front; "Margaret A. Hemingway's Wedding dress, married June 21, 1854" handwritten on the boning inside bodice; dress was hand-stitched.
31 inches (chest), 22 inches (waist), 56.5 inches (center front length), 56 inches (center back length), other measurements: Hem = 2 yards; 35
"Margaret A. Heminway's wedding dress, married June 21, 1854" handwritten on boning inside bodice

objects.title: Cream Lace Dress with Lavender Accents

properties.value: Cream Lace Dress with Lavender Accents

Cream lace dress with short puffed sleeves and lavender trim. High neck, S-curve boned bodice with vertical lavender velvet trim and pleated satin waistband. Natural waist skirt with fullness at hem and train in back.

objects.title: Wedding Dress of Isabel Miller Board

properties.value: Wedding Dress of Isabel Miller Board

Two piece dress of tan brocade with light blue accents and satin ribbon of light blue and brown; hourglass silhouette. Bodice (a) is boned; band collar closes at center back with metal hooks and eyes; leg o'mutton sleeves; four back princess seams, two side seams, fitted panels on each side with brown stain ribbon in v- shape on bodice front and back, center front gathered panels closing over separate fitted lining with metal hook and eye closures; bows at center front and center back waist, wrists, shoulders, and neck; natural straight waist; twisted edging of brocade and brown stain at waist; dress shields in both sleeves. Skirt (b) is gored with pleated back; floor-length; hook and eye closures at center back; bows of light blue and brown ribbons at front left.
Made specially for Mme E. Saunders,/ Fashionable Dressmaking,/ Louisville, KY./ c-m/ 3 printed on left dress shield

Images © Vassar College Costume Collection. Images in this collection may be used for teaching, classroom presentation, and research purposes only. For reuse, reproduction and publication of these images, contact costumeshop@vassar.edu.

A foam mannequin was carved to accommodate the lower, smaller waistline, then the mannequin was padded with batting to match the size of dress. A cotton knit cover was placed over the padding, and a full petticoat was dressed on the mannequin to help support the skirt.
For Better and For Worse, Vassar College, Spring 2013

This dress was worn by Isabel Miller, grandmother of Isabel Plambeck (Vassar class of 1962) and Mary Agnes Norman (Vassar class of 1959) and mother of Isabel Board Foshee (Vassar class of 1931), for her wedding to Milton Board in Hardinsburg, Kentucky in 1895.

objects.title: Two piece day ensemble in rust red

properties.value: Two piece day ensemble in rust red

The peaked sleeve cap identifies this dress from the beginning of the 1890's.  It has grown as the bustle has shrunk.  The bodice is a "tailor-made", with revers (lapels), tail and a suggested waistcoat (vest) and high collared white neck insert.  The skirt falls smoothly over the hips, flaring at the base. There is a modified bustle of steel and ties built into the back of the skirt.  The outfit may be one predominant color but it combines silk faille, velvet and brocade.  The name of the dressmaker is woven into the silk petersham waist belt inside the bodice.
Smith College Historic Clothing Collection (Northampton, Massachusetts, United States)

Matching flared cotton sateen skirt (b) is knee-length, with an elastic waistband, metal zipper at side, felt lining, stripes radiating from waist to hem.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, ca 1949, https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/105736.|Reeder, Jan Glier. “Elsa Schiaparelli (1890–1973) | Essay | Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History | The Metropolitan Museum of Art.” The Met’s Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History, https://www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/elsa/hd_elsa.htm. light stains under arms; lots of tears in lining of skirt
To support the fullness of the skirt for display, the mannequin was dressed in a flared petticoat with layers of stiff netting.

Allen donation 2.19|Box 4 - packing list quote from Terry Allen: '5. Givenchy hand painted silk stripes, strapless, full skirt; owned by Elizabeth De la Rochefoucauld Allen, Nancy's sister-in-law. Bought in Paris, at Givenchy. Date - 1945?"|Notes from Anna Weincrot, 1/6/04: 'LABEL: Givenchy'filename="1936 Givenchy stripped Jane M_1."|tag has been sewn over; can we look at it?|photos of labels taken 5/17||Formerly labeled 'Givenchy hand painted silk stripes, strapless, full skirt" in fact it is not Givenchy, but has a label for Schiap-sport

This piece came to us in two pieces, as a skirt and a top, but the finishing on the waists of both pieces indicates that it may once have been one dress. While the donor told us that it was a Givenchy piece, the label within reads "Schiap-Sport," indicating Elsa Schiaparelli's line. Research from the V and A Collections website tells us that Hubert Givenchy did work for Schiaparelli for four years before beginning his own design house in Paris in 1952 ("Day Ensemble"), so both could be true. The dates are still uncertain. The label in its entirety reads "Schiap-Sport -21 Place Vendome Paris 46," indicating a date of 1946. While we have been unable to find a match for this dress in other collections to confirm its date, there are a few strapless (and sometimes striped) dresses to compare it with ("Elsa Schiaparelli" [ca. 1948] and "Elsa Schiaparelli" [ca. 1949]), and a search for the Schiap-Sport label on the website of the Metropolitan Museum of Art shows that it seems to have been more popular in the late part of Elsa's career (1940s and 50s). Elsa Schiaparelli was born in Rome, began her career in America, opened her first atelier in Paris, moved back to New York in 1941, and returned to Paris in 1945. She worked with surrealist artists Salvador Dali and Jean Cocteau, was associated with Man Ray and Gabrielle Picabia, the wife of Francis Picabia, and was known for blurring the line between dressmaking and art. Schiaparelli closed her doors in 1954, but not before creating a legacy that would go on to inspire designers like Geoffrey Beene, Charles James, and Yves Saint Laurent (Reeder).
Arden Kirkland 2004-05-07|Margaret Thompson & Madeleine Boesche 2/13/10;|Julia Fields Fall 2011

objects.title: Wedding Dress of Henrietta S. Robinson

properties.value: Wedding Dress of Henrietta S. Robinson

Wedding ensemble with components of cream silk crepe back satin, lace, metal, pearl, wax, and leather. Dress (a): bias cut; bodice with curved seam under bust; two-layered sleeves below with round buttons on lower portion of center back sleeves; lace cowl neck; inset buttons at center back; natural waist line; full length; straight skirt with flounced train which is higher at center back; two box pleats at front of skirt where skirt meets added flounce. Belt (b): crepe back satin with metal buckle adorned with pearl; closure at center front. Veil (c ) of net with applied wide lace border; circlet of net twisted with strand of pearls; wax orange blossoms. Shoes (d and e): t-strap heels of cream fabric over leather with panels of silver intertwined.

properties.value: This dress is an example of a Victorian half-mourning evening gown.  Victorian society took its mourning very seriously.  Rules of bereavement reached every aspect of Victorian life, the strictest being in the matters of fashion.  There are two stages, deep or full mourning and half-mourning.  Women's deep mourning garments were made of black crepe, a lusterless fabric and her social engagements were strongly restricted.  A widow progressed to half-mourning after a year which allowed for a black silk dress and jewelry made of pearls, amethysts, black cut glass and jet.  After a year of half-mourning widows could wear colors freely but many followed Queen Victoria's lead and wore black for the rest of their lives.
Smith College Historic Clothing Collection (Northampton, Massachusetts, United States)
Permission for educational use only granted by Costume Department, Theatre Department, Smith College, Northampton, Massachusetts USA

properties.value: Dress: long; cotton; small geometric print; buttons down front to waistband; gathered bodice; Long sleeves; light brown, burgundy, black, and white design; hand worked scalloped trim, covered buttons

This day dress is elegant in its simplicity.  The full sleeves are cut on the bias in one piece and set under epaulettes or caps.  The straight/horizontal waist and round neck are finished with self-fabric piping.  The skirt is made of 8 panels, each 19" wide, all gathered in tight guaging, an accordian pleating that compresses these 128" of fabric into a waist circumference of 25 1/2".Compared to the wide arc of the sleeves and with wide base of the skirt, the waist looks especially small.  Likely the skirt appreared to float over a large cage crinoline which felt liberating to women who had struggled with layers of bulky petticoats before these watch-spring steel hoops were an option.  There is a pocket set into the right waist seam.  The dress is lined with caramel colored polished cotton.  Narrow brown woolen braid binds the hem, protecting the silk from dirt and wear.
Smith College Historic Clothing Collection (Northampton, Massachusetts, United States)

properties.value: Teal two-piece dress; silk taffeta; fish pattern; red velvet at waist, collar, and cuffs; skirt (a) ankle-length bell skirt; seven panel construction; natural waist; two ruffles at hem; brown linen full lining; bodice (b) natural waist; two-piece long sleeve with slightly flared red velvet cuff; blue silk panel center front running waist to collar; both band and lapel collars; red velvet with 5-9 lines decorative blue stitching at edges; brown linen full lining with boning. Silvery blue silk, diagonal weave taffeta, fish motif; natural polished cotton; green silk velvet; red silk velvet; red taffeta; periwinkle silk; white cotton waistband; hemp hem lining; metal hook and eyes, brassFitted bodice; full skirta. skirt: floor length; fitted at waist; five panels; two tiers of ruffles at hem; velvet at inner hem, lined with hemp; polished cotton skirt lining; one pocket on right hip; cotton waistband, later addition; hook and eyes at waist center backb. bodice: waist length, five piece; fittled two piece full length sleeve, gathered shoulders, split cuff on either side of wrist; mandarin collar with inset periwinkle silk over center front of bodice extending to waist; red velvet lapels; red velvet waist band; 18 interior brass hooks and eyes to close center front, 3 to close neck; boning at waist; three tapered panels in back .

objects.title: Two piece day ensemble in beige, pale green, and purple

properties.value: Two piece day ensemble in beige, pale green, and purple

This day outfit, from the late bustle era, was worn by Kate Morris Cone, a student in the first graduating class of Smith College in 1879.  The fawn wool bodice is cut in a "tailor-made" style, tightly fitted with an obvious CF button closure, long cuffed sleeves and an elaborate tail, all to suggest a man's tail coat.  These details are in contrast with the lace trim at the collar and cuffs, the three large purple bows on the wool swags and the three rows of narrow box pleats all around the skirt hem.  The foundation skirt is made in a watered silk taffeta.  It would be worn over a separate cage bustle. This combination of different colors and fabrics is popular at this time.
Smith College Historic Clothing Collection (Northampton, Massachusetts, United States)

properties.value: Day dresses of the twenties preserve a neat, business-like simplicity in its tubular, extremely slender shape, as described by C.W. Cunnington.  Female breasts and waists are obliterated in a boyish shape.  But in the later half of the decade, there are suggestions of a softening, especially in the skirt that begins to flare loosely, freed from straight, precise pleats. This sports dress shows just such a flare in the skirt that is made of 3 panels.  Two of the panels are semi-circular; they join at the center front on the straight grain, and finish at the side back, stitched to the side back panel that is all on the straight grain.  This construction places a bias curve on the sides that leaves plenty of room for any sports activities.   Madelyn Shaw, Guest Curator of the exhibit, Silk in New England Society, 1730-1930, here at the Smith College Museum of Art, wrote further about the material: By 1920, the American silk industry was the largest in the world, consuming more raw silk from Japan and China than all of Europe put together.  Constrained by the shortages of wool and cotton during World War I, American silk manufacturers developed new silk and silk-mixed fabrics to encourage American women to wear silk around the clock and across the seasons.  Sports silks, like sportswear, were truly American inventions and were exported to markets in Europe and South America.two-piece tan silk tweed  sports dress trimmed with silk ribbon
Smith College Historic Clothing Collection (Northampton, Massachusetts, United States)
